title: Elephant Vanishes book fonts
content:
Can anyone help with these fonts used on Haruki Murakami's first edition book:

the cover has two faces - a sans and a serif

and the inside title pages uses a(or a couple of) sans serif(s) in several weights, does anyone know what they are?

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [acbe\_12.JPG](http://web.archive.org/web/20140806134150/http:/typophile.com/files/acbe_12.JPG) | 17.83 KB |
| [ab74\_12.JPG](http://web.archive.org/web/20140806134150/http:/typophile.com/files/ab74_12.JPG) | 26.91 KB |
author: Dash_X

comments.content: Why not Helvetica Neue (extended) and Garamond?

The Sans on the cover seems to have a short middle arm on the E, so I suggest something like [Engravers Gothic](http://web.archive.org/web/20140806134150/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/paratype/engravers-gothic/) or maybe Interstate widened.

The Sans inside the book is not the same, and might be Helvetica, as Ryuk suggested.

- Mike Yanega

I'm also not convinced that Garamond is the right serif for the cover, although it's hard to see the detail well enough. The M seems more splayed looking, and I thought [Janson](http://web.archive.org/web/20140806134150/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/adobe/janson-text/) might be closer. Also because the 'k' upper arm seems so much lighter in your sample.

If you can get a closer view that would help a lot.

- Mike Yanega

thanks for all the help, heres a hi-res of the cover - could the sans have been pulled from an old catalogue?

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140806134150im_/http:/typophile.com/files/murakami_elephantvanishes_5464.jpg)

I wish I could say that helped, and I guess it did in a way, but it hasn't pointed to an answer yet. That 'k' is quite unusual. The 'a' does look like Janson to me, but nothing else matches very well. The M looks more like Romana than anything else, but the rest of the lower case isn't Romana.

Can you tell that I'm stumped? I would really like to know what this is now.

- Mike Yanega

The closest I can seem to manage is a customization/distortion of De Vinne. This image (below) is admittedly crude because it was made by distorting a test drive image, but I think it shows the possibility that a typeface like this could have been artificially condensed/manipulated to produce something similar. This De Vinne was the [one from Wooden Type Fonts](http://web.archive.org/web/20140806134150/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/woodentypefonts/de-vinne/).

Perhaps the initials were not distorted as much, but if you look at the basic font, I see a strong resemblance to the typeface used for the book cover. Am I imagining things?

- Mike Yanega

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140806134150im_/http:/typophile.com/files/HarukiMurakamiDeVinneSim_5904.gif)
